case_name: Rate-payers of the town of Akola v. Municipal Committee, Akola

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 234/60.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 234/60.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1958, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 201 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1958, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 201 of 1958.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J. on January 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR., J.-This is an appeal against the jugdment and order of the High Court of Judicature of Bombay at Nagpur dismissing a petition under Arts. 226 227 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the imposition of the octroi tax under s. 66 1  e  of the C. P. Berar Municipal Act  Act II of 1922  hereinafter termed the Act.

facts.text: Appellants were the petitioners in the High Court and are some of the rate-payers of the town of Akola in the erstwhile State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who were the petitioners in the High Court are some of the rate-payers of the town of Akola in the erstwhile State of Bombay and respondent No. 1 is the Municipal Committee, Akola.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 is the Municipal Committee, Akola.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who were the petitioners in the High Court are some of the rate-payers of the town of Akola in the erstwhile State of Bombay and respondent No. 1 is the Municipal Committee, Akola.

facts.text: On November 11, 1957, respondent No. 1 passed a resolution to impose an octroi tax on animals and goods brought within the limits of the Akola Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: On November 11, 1957, respondent No. 1 passed a resolution to impose an octroi tax on animals and goods brought within the limits of the Akola Municipality.

facts.text: The resolution and the draft Rules of Assessment and Collection were forwarded by the Akola Municipality to the State Government for publication.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution and the draft Rules of Assessment and Collection were later on forwarded by the Akola Municipality to the State Government for publication.

facts.text: A notification dated January 3, 1958, was published in the Bombay Government Gazette on January 16, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification dated January 3, 1958, was published in the Bombay Government Gazette on January 16, 1958.

facts.text: The Gazette Notification contained the draft rules, the schedule of goods liable to octroi duty and the rates to be charged.

anchor.surface_text: This Gazette Notification companytained the draft rules, the schedule of goods liable to octroi duty and the rates to be charged. This was in accordance with the requirements of s. 67 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 affixed the proposed rules on the Notice Board of the Committee and published in the local newspapers.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, the Municipal Committee, affixed on the Notice Board of the Committee and published in the local newspapers the proposed rules for the imposition of the tax

facts.text: Appellants object that the draft of the System of Assessment was not published along with the proposed rules.

anchor.surface_text: but the objection of the appellants is that they did number publish along with them the draft of the System of Assessment .

facts.text: A pamphlet in Marathi language was distributed in the town of Akola.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that a pamphlet in Marathi language was distributed in the town of Akola and the proposals were also published in the local newspaper Jan-Sewak.

facts.text: Proposals were published in the local newspaper Jan-Sewak.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that a pamphlet in Marathi language was distributed in the town of Akola and the proposals were also published in the local newspaper Jan-Sewak.

facts.text: Objections to the proposals were filed by some of the rate-payers of the town of Akola.

anchor.surface_text: Objections to the proposals were filed by some of the rate-payers of the town of Akola and all of them were companysidered

facts.text: A resolution was passed by the Municipal Committee on March 3, 1958, after considering all objections.

anchor.surface_text: and a resolution was passed by the Municipal Committee on March 3, 1958, and that is the resolution which was challenged in the petition filed in the High Court

facts.text: Petition filed in High Court on April 14, 1958, challenging the March 3, 1958 resolution and praying for quashing and prohibitory order against State Government.

anchor.surface_text: by a petition dated April 14, 1958, p raying for the quashing of the resolution and for the issuing of a prohibitory order against the State Government against sanctioning the proposal sent by the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: Rule issued by High Court on April 18, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On April 18, 1958, a rule was issued by the High Court to the opposite parties calling upon them to show cause why the, order as prayed should number be made.

facts.text: Notice served on Special Government Pleader on May 9, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice was served on the Special Government Pleader on May 9, 1958

facts.text: Special Government Pleader put in appearance on June 17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and the Special Government Pleader put in his appearance on June 17, 1958.

facts.text: Interim injunction issued on June 23, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23, 1958, an interim injunction was issued

facts.text: Final notification issued by Government on June 19, 1958 approving the proposal to impose octroi tax.

anchor.surface_text: but previous to that on June 19, 1958, a final numberification was issued by the Government approving of the proposal to impose the octroi tax.

facts.text: Petition was allowed to be amended as a consequence.

anchor.surface_text: As a companysequence of this the petition was allowed to be amended

facts.text: High Court dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: but ultimately the High Court dismissed the petition and this appeal has been brought on a certificate of the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal brought on a certificate of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: but ultimately the High Court dismissed the petition and this appeal has been brought on a certificate of the High Court.

facts.text: Legality of imposition challenged on ground of no full compliance with mandatory requirements of s. 67(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the legality is challenged is that there was numberfull companypliance with the mandatory requirements of s. 67 2  of the Act.

facts.text: It is admitted that Gazette dated January 16, 1958 contained draft rules with articles to be taxed, rates, etc., conforming to s.67(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that in the Gazette dated January 16, 1958, the draft rules were published which companytained the articles to be taxed, the rate or rates at which they were to be taxed and what articles were number to be taxed.

facts.text: Contention that in Jan-Sewak local newspaper, draft rules in regard to System of Assessment were not published.

anchor.surface_text: But the companytention raised is that in the Jan-Sewak, a local Marathi newspaper, the rules which were published companytained the articles to be taxed, the rate or rates at which they were to be taxed, but the draft rules in regard to System of Assessment were number published along with it.

facts.text: High Court held there was sufficient compliance with s.67(2), system of assessment meant only the stage of imposition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out that what was done was a sufficient companypliance with the provisions of s. 67 2  and that the words System of Assessment meant only the stage of the imposition of the tax and number other stages as a whole.

facts.text: Supreme Court opinion: there has been compliance with s.67(2), publication of rules relating to rates sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there has been a companypliance with the provision of s. 67 2  and that the publication of the rules relating to the rates at which the tax had been imposed was sufficient to companyply with the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: The Rule relating to publication under s. 67 is as follows - A numberice under section 67 2  of the intention of the municipal companymittee to impose a tax, or under section 68 3  of the proposal of the companymittee to increase the amount of rate of any tax, shall be forwarded to the State Government through the Deputy Commissioner for publication in the Madhya Pradesh Gazette. The numberice under section 67 2 shall be accompanied by draft rules for the assessment and companylection of the tax.

issues.text: Whether there was full compliance with the mandatory requirements of s. 67(2) of the Act regarding publication for the imposition of the octroi tax?

anchor.surface_text: The sole question which has been debated before us is the legality of the imposition. The ground on which the legality is challenged is that there was numberfull companypliance with the mandatory requirements of s. 67 2  of the Act. It is, therefore, necessary to deal with the relevant provisions of the Act. Chapter IX of the Act deals with Imposition,

issues.text: Whether the 'system of assessment' in s. 67(2) means the whole procedure of taxation including assessment, collection and refunds or only the imposition stage?

The High Court has pointed out that what was done was a sufficient companypliance with the provisions of s. 67 2  and that the words System of Assessment meant only the stage of the imposition of the tax and number other stages as a whole. anchor.surface_text: The scheme of s. 67 appears to be this that when a Municipal Committee wishes to impose a tax it has to pass a resolution at a special meeting and then it has to publish its resolution for imposition of that tax so that the rate- payers may be able to place their objections against the imposition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gazette publication conformed to s.67(2) requirements including draft rules, articles, rates, exemptions; local publication of notice with rates in newspaper and pamphlet complies with publication rule specifying notice affixation and local publication, not full draft rules; objections considered.

holdings.text: the words System of Assessment do not necessarily mean the whole procedure of taxation, i.e., imposition, collection and procedure in regard to collection and refunds.

anchor.surface_text: Read together these provisions of the Act support the decision of the High Court that the words System of Assessment do number necessarily mean the whole procedure of taxation, i.e., imposition, companylection and procedure in regard to companylection and refunds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.71 (assessment/evasion), 76 (collection/evasion), 85 (refund) shows they separately regulate post-imposition stages, so s.67(2) 'system of assessment' limited to imposition stage.

holdings.text: what is to be affixed on the notice board and at conspicuous places of the town is the notice and not the draft rules relating to assessment and collection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Publication rule under s.67 explicitly requires local publication/affixation of the notice only, after Gazette publication of notice with draft rules.
